rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Noticing emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 

Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions ‚Äì even the difficult ones.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Noticing emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 

Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions ‚Äì even the difficult ones.

media_title.eng: How will talking about feelings with my children help me and my family?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get really angry upset and you don‚Äôt know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. You start with noticing and accepting all the emotions we have. We are all human.

rows.media_title: How will talking about feelings with my children help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get really angry upset and you don‚Äôt know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. You start with noticing and accepting all the emotions we have. We are all human.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs take a look at how @data.characters.f3_mother.name and her daughter, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, talk about feelings in a practical way:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs take a look at how @data.characters.f3_mother.name and her daughter, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, talk about feelings in a practical way:

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?

character_2_text.eng: Let‚Äôs play with the ball outside!

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?
rows.character_2_text: Let‚Äôs play with the ball outside!

character_2_text.eng: I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name. It‚Äôs not easy, let‚Äôs practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.

rows.character_2_text: I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name. It‚Äôs not easy, let‚Äôs practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.

rows.character_1_text: Five kicks in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name!

character_1_text.eng: Five kicks in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name!
Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name

rows.character_1_text: Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs talk this through together. What happened when @data.characters.f3_mother.name and @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name decided to play ball outside?

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs talk this through together. What happened when @data.characters.f3_mother.name and @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name decided to play ball outside?

quiz_1_question.eng: Why does @data.characters.f3_mother.name name @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name‚Äôs feelings when she‚Äôs feeling angry and proud?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Not quite. Naming emotions might not make someone feel better right away. The goal is to help her recognize her feelings so she can handle them better next time.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: To help @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name learn to recognise her own emotions

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That‚Äôs right. By naming @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name‚Äôs emotions, @data.characters.f3_mother.name models an important skill.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: To teach @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name how to solve problems on her own.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Not really. While solving problems is important, the main goal here is to help @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name recognize her emotions. Once she knows what she‚Äôs feeling, she‚Äôll be better at solving problems next time.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: To distract @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name from what‚Äôs bothering her.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Not quite. The goal isn‚Äôt to take her mind off her feelings. By naming her emotions, @data.characters.f3_mother.name is helping @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name understand what she‚Äôs feeling, so she can deal with it better next time.

quiz_2_question.eng: What can we learn from how @data.characters.f3_mother.name talks about @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name‚Äôs emotions?

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Yes, @data.characters.f3_mother.name shows us that it is important to identify both positive *and* difficult emotions for our children.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: She accepts whatever emotions @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name‚Äôs is feeling

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Yes, @data.characters.f3_mother.name shows us how we can talk about positive *and* difficult emotions with our children in a helpful way.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: She uses words to describe @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name‚Äôs emotions

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Yes, @data.characters.f3_mother.name shows us how we can talk about positive *and* difficult emotions with our children in a helpful way.

quiz_2_option_4_text.eng: She shares her own feelings with @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: Yes, by talking about her own feeling of happiness, @data.characters.f3_mother.name models how her daughter can do the same.

quiz_2_feedback_5.eng: Yes, @data.characters.f3_mother.name shows us that her daughter‚Äôs difficult emotions are not something she needs to ignore or be scared of..

quiz_3_question.eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f3_mother.name had criticised or ignored @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name‚Äôs frustration?

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to help our children learn how to deal with their feelings before they get too big.

quiz_3_option_2_text.eng: The same problem would happen again next time

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn how to deal with their emotions.

quiz_3_option_3_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_daughter_7.name would not have learned how to catch a ball

quiz_3_feedback_3.eng: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn new skills.

rows.quiz_3_feedback_3: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn new skills.

rows.text_1_facilitator: With these three tips, you can help your child learn to manage their emotions well.

text_1_facilitator.eng: With these three tips, you can help your child learn to manage their emotions well.

section_1_text.eng: Recognise the *positive* and *difficult* emotions that you and your child feel.

section_1_extra_text.eng: To recognise feelings, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child‚Äôs words and actions.

section_2_text.eng: Be open to how you and your child feel. All feelings are okay.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
There are six basic emotions. Each send us an important message:
 üòä Happy: Keep doing things that make you feel good. 

‚òπÔ∏è Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.

üò† Angry: Stand up for yourself and set limits.

ü§¢ Disgusted: Move away from something you don't like.

üòØ Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.

üò® Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

section_3_text.eng:
Use words to describe your and your child‚Äôs emotions, so they can learn to do the same. 
 
This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions!

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Describe how you see your child‚Äôs emotion in a calm way. For example:
 
*‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry?‚Äù*
 
Share your own feelings with your child. For example: 
 
*‚ÄúI know I feel the same way when I can‚Äôt go out when I want to.‚Äù*
 
This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs put the tips you have learnt in practice:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs put the tips you have learnt in practice:

quiz_1_question.eng: @data.characters.f1_mother.name's son is throwing a tantrum at the front door. It's time to put on his shoes and the family is running late. Tying his shoes is a challenge and he wants to do it himself. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he‚Äôs feeling.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated. Sit down and help him name his feelings.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he's more calm and praise him for naming his feelings and for the good effort during their practise session!

rows.quiz_1_question: @data.characters.f1_mother.name's son is throwing a tantrum at the front door. It's time to put on his shoes and the family is running late. Tying his shoes is a challenge and he wants to do it himself. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he‚Äôs feeling.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated. Sit down and help him name his feelings.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he's more calm and praise him for naming his feelings and for the good effort during their practise session!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Your home activity is to talk with your child about their feelings during one-on-one time today. It can be something simple, like noticing that they find joy when they play!

text_1_facilitator.eng: Your home activity is to talk with your child about their feelings during one-on-one time today. It can be something simple, like noticing that they find joy when they play!

media_title.eng: @data.characters.media_female_8.name taught her daughter valuable skills by naming her emotions. Tap play to hear more

media_transcript.eng:
My daughter used to get so frustrated and angry when she did not get her way. She would shout and scream, even when we went out, and I would also feel very angry and embarrassed. 

When I learned about emotions, I started to name and acknowledge her emotions. I helped her understand that it is okay to feel angry sometimes, but that she can show it in a different way. Now, she will tell me when she starts to feel angry, and we can find a solution together that works for everyone.

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you help your child notice their feelings during one-on-one time today?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That‚Äôs great! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Give it a try! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Learning to share emotions with our children can be challenging. Take a minute after one-on-one time today to think through the emotions you saw your child display. You might also want to think about the things that you felt!
